question: I made a verbal agreement about 3.5 years ago. It was my idea and I came to him. The terms, as I remember them:
question_tags: Independent contractor,LLC (limited liability company),Business partnerships,Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Business,Employment as an independent contractor,Contractor agreement
answers:
I agree with my colleagues. In California, two or more person sharing profits is considered a partnership whether or not profits were actually made. In your verbal agreement, the percentage breakdown would be considered profit sharing. Therefore you are in a partnership. To minimize confusion and problems in the future, you should consider establishing a partnership agreement or an LLC depending on your situation.

You should probably consider contacting a business attorney to assist you.

Disclosure: This communication shall not be considered to have been given under or to have formed an attorney-client relationship.

These oral agreements are enforceable, although it's always harder to enforce an oral agreement, which is why is best to put things in writing. You should take partnership arrangements more seriously, since partners are liable for each other's debts, even if you think you "held all the debt" in this partnership. Your original partnership deal, if it lacked a specific dissolution mechanism would be governed by CA partnership law, and a leaving member would generally be entitled to the value of their share at the time they leave.

You should hire a lawyer to prepare written agreements that spells out the respective rights and responsibilities of those involved, so you can provide for the necessary meetings and consequences for not meeting obligations. For your prior arrangement, you need a buyout agreement, and a new partnership agreement, or an independent contractor agreement. You also should consider forming an LLC instead of a partnership, which would protect you from personal liability from creditors and colleagues.

You formed a partnership, even if it was only verbal. You acted on it for 2.5 years. Product was not successful so you developed a similar product. That product is probably partnership property.

You and he should enter into a written agreement on terms you will both be happy with. You might want to consult a business law attorney.
